Conseco called off its $3.25 billion takeover of Kemper. The move came after Citibank, the lead lender, indicated that it probably would not be able to finance even a lowered bid, one person close to the negotiations said. [ Page D1. ]

Sony and Matsushita have charted different paths into movie making, and at different paces. And the race has not gone to the swiftest. The flashy Sony has reported big losses on its studios, while the cautious Matsushita has enjoyed profits. [ D1. ]

A financial adviser to Borden had a $10 million incentive to complete a deal for the company to be acquired by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts at the same time another suitor was trying to meet with the Borden board, a regulatory filing shows. [ D1. ]
MCI Communications plans to announce a broad package of access services that includes an electronic shopping mall for consumers and high-speed connections for businesses. [ D2. ]
Whoever said "you can't take it with you" didn't look closely at the career of Leonard Levine, former president of two limited partnerships also serviced by his real estate company. [ D4. ]

USAir has appointed a retired Air Force general as its chief of safety operations and hired an outside aviation consultant firm to conduct an independent audit of its flight operations. [ A10. ] International
The Swiss are seeing a knock-down, drag-out fight over control of the huge Union Bank of Switzerland. [ D1. ]

Russian scientists have set off an international debate, after disclosing that for more than three decades the Government has secretly pumped billions of gallons of atomic waste directly into the earth, and continues to do so today. [ A1. ] The Economy
Nasdaq appointed former Senator Warren Rudman to head an independent committee to review the market's operations. [ D1. ]
Senator Bob Dole told Administration officials that he would be more inclined to vote for a world trade pact if the White House dropped certain objections to a cut in the capital gains tax. [ A1. ]
California regulators are pushing insurers to allow a member of a homosexual couple to buy life insurance on the other partner, and name himself or herself as beneficiary. [ A13. ] The Media Business

David Letterman faces the challenge of simultaneously proving himself and holding up a faltering network -- not once, but twice. Mr. Letterman ventures into prime time with a CBS special, then, in his regular show, he tries to fend off an invasion of his home turf by Jay Leno, of NBC's "Tonight" show. [ D1. ]
Time Inc. plans to announce that a new magazine based on "This Old House," the highest-rated regular series on public television, will be tested on newsstands next year. [ D5. ]
A new crop of publications has sprouted up in Washington in the last year or so, a wide-ranging collection of quarterlies, bimonthlies and weeklies. [ D5. ]
A BBC news program broadcast on shortwave radio has become a growing source of information for Africans, who are among the world's most avid shortwave radio listeners. [ D5. ]

Chrysler has teamed with House Beautiful magazine to create a traveling mini-exhibit of work by Frank Lloyd Wright, as part of a campaign to push the new Cirrus sedan. Advertising. [ D6. ] Today's Columns
A Texas company has patented a recombinant gene that it hopes will help eliminate acid rain. Sabra Chartrand. Patents. [ D2. ]
One of the nastiest election fights of 1994 ends today. The battle is for control of a real estate investment trust called American Industrial Properties. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ D4. ]
